The Herpesviridae family includes a large number of viruses with long linear dsDNA genomes: it comprises more than 100 pathogens classified into three subfamilies, alpha-, beta- and gammaherpesvirinae, which mainly differ in the host target cells. Among all human herpesviruses (HHVs), nine species routinely infect humans, are extremely widespread and responsible for the onset of several different diseases, such as orolabial and genital herpes, chickenpox and shingles, mononucleosis and different types of cancer ( Table 2 ). Interestingly, more than 90% of adults are infected with at least one of these.
